title: Piercing
author: Sarah Mintz

content: Are you thinking about getting an ear or facial piercing ? Here are some key questions to ask yourself before you get pierced:
bullets: Do you have your parents' permission? Most places require you to have parental consent if you are under age 18. So be sure to check with your parents before getting pierced.
What does your school say ? Some schools don't allow students to have facial piercings.
Are you looking for a job? Some jobs don't allow employees to have facial piercings. Make sure the piercing is appropriate for your daily life.
Are you thinking of donating blood? Some organizations don't accept blood from people who have been pierced within the last year.
Are you up to date with your vaccines? It's a good idea to make sure you're vaccinated for diseases such as hepatitis B and tetanus before you get a piercing.
Have you given it enough thought? If you have any doubt, consider holding off on a decision to get pierced.

Have you given it enough thought? If you have any doubt, consider holding off on a decision to get pierced.

sections.heading: Is piercing safe?
content: When done in a clean and professional environment, piercing is usually safe. But if piercing equipment is unclean, there is a risk of getting blood-transmitted diseases. These include:
Even in a sterile (germ-free) environment, some common risks of piercing are:
bullets: In general, it's a good idea to talk to your doctor before a piercing if you:
Have a heart or other chronic condition

sections.heading: Where should I go to get my piercing done?
content: A sterile environment is the most important thing to consider when deciding where to go to get pierced.
Here are some tips for finding a safe place to get your piercing done:
NEVER do this:
bullets: Check with your doctor. Some doctors' offices will do basic ear piercings.
Research piercing shops that use safe procedures or are licensed by the state. R egulations for commercial piercing locations vary by location, and licenses are not always required.
If you are going to get the piercing in a mall, make sure employees use a sterile, single-use piercing gun.
Pierce yourself or have a friend pierce you
Get pierced in a shop that looks unclean, makes you uncomfortable, or doesn't answer all your questions.

sections.heading: How do I know that my piercing shop is safe and sterile?
content: Many states regulate body piercing, but not all. Before getting your piercing, you should always check for these signs of a safe piercing environment:
bullets: The piercer washes their hands with germicidal soap.
The piercer wears fresh disposable gloves.
The shop uses an autoclave (a special sterilizing machine).
The equipment is sterilized or disposable.
The needle is new and disposed of in a special container after use.

content_blocks.text: Many states regulate body piercing, but not all. Before getting your piercing, you should always check for these signs of a safe piercing environment:
associated_bullets: The piercer washes their hands with germicidal soap.
The piercer wears fresh disposable gloves.
The shop uses an autoclave (a special sterilizing machine).
The equipment is sterilized or disposable.
The needle is new and disposed of in a special container after use.

sections.heading: Should I get pierced with a piercing gun or a needle?
content: Needles are generally considered cleaner and easier to sterilize than piercing guns. Your piercer should only use a piercing gun that is for one-time use or has sterilized disposable cassettes.
Piercing guns should only be used on earlobe piercings. That's because they can cause more damage to the skin tissue than needles.

content_blocks.text: Needles are generally considered cleaner and easier to sterilize than piercing guns. Your piercer should only use a piercing gun that is for one-time use or has sterilized disposable cassettes.
Piercing guns should only be used on earlobe piercings. That's because they can cause more damage to the skin tissue than needles.

sections.heading: How long will it take for my piercing to heal?
content: Healing times can vary depending on the location of the piercing. Here are the average healing times for common piercings:
Remember, with mouth or lip piercing, jewelry can cause cracks in your teeth or receding gums. Lip piercings and mouth piercings can get infected more easily.

Remember, with mouth or lip piercing, jewelry can cause cracks in your teeth or receding gums. Lip piercings and mouth piercings can get infected more easily.

sections.heading: How can I care for my new piercing?
content: Your piercer will give you specific instructions for cleaning your piercing. Here are some general dos and don'ts for new piercings:
Do:
Don't:
bullets: Wash your hands before cleaning the piercing.
Clean the pierced area with antibacterial soap or hypochlorous acid..
Soak the piercing in salt water. This will cleanse it and loosen crusty formations.
Rinse with an alcohol-free, antibacterial mouthwash or hypochlorous acid.(for tongue and lip piercings).
Pick at or touch the piercing. This can irritate it and lead to infection.
Use alcohol or hydrogen peroxide to clean the piercing. This can dry out your skin and break down new tissue.
Use public pools or hot tubs while the piercing is healing.
Wear makeup during the healing process (for ear or facial piercings).

sections.heading: What happens if my piercing becomes infected?
content: Some temporary pain or swelling is normal after a piercing. But if pain continues, it could mean an infection.

content_blocks.text: Some temporary pain or swelling is normal after a piercing. But if pain continues, it could mean an infection.

content: Be extra careful if you get an oral piercing. These are more susceptible to infection because of bacteria in the mouth. Contact with jewelry against the teeth can also cause your teeth to crack or chip.
Watch out for these signs of infection:
If you think your piercing may be infected:
bullets: Pain that does not go away after a day or two
Don't take out the jewelry. This will cause the hole to close up and may trap the infection.

content_blocks.text: Be extra careful if you get an oral piercing. These are more susceptible to infection because of bacteria in the mouth. Contact with jewelry against the teeth can also cause your teeth to crack or chip.
Watch out for these signs of infection:
associated_bullets: Pain that does not go away after a day or two

content_blocks.text: If you think your piercing may be infected:
associated_bullets: Don't take out the jewelry. This will cause the hole to close up and may trap the infection.

sections.heading: What if I am sensitive to metal?
content: Some people have sensitivities to certain kinds of metal jewelry. Signs you could be allergic to your new piercing include:
To avoid an allergic reaction, use only nontoxic metals, such as:
bullets: Itching or burning when piercing is cleaned

sources: Palo Alto Medical Foundation web site: "Piercing."
meta_description: WebMD answers teens' questions about piercings -- in the ear and elsewhere on the body -- including risks and important safety precautions.
